properties.title: Historical Wildlife Use of Baxter Creek
properties.description:
Grizzly and black bears

mountain lions

coyotes

bobcats

wolves

mule deer

tule elk...

 once roamed the hills of El Cerrito and Richmond and drank from the streams

properties.title: Historical Wildlife Use of Baxter Creek
properties.description:
The riparian (or creek-side) vegetation along the streams provided food and shelter for many birds and small mammals like 

foxes
squirrels
brush rabbits

...Whose remains were discovered years later in prehistoric middens, or shellmounds along the creek

properties.title: Wetland Ecology
properties.description: Snowy Egret preys in a mudflat

properties.title: Wetland Ecology
properties.description: Historically, eneath the cordgrass, saltgrass, and pickleweed of the salt marsh, Huchiuns found bent-nosed clams and snails and within the tidal channels caught sturgeon, bat rays, thresher sharks, and leopard sharks!

properties.title: Soil Sample #1
properties.description: At mouth of Baxter Creek adjacent to pedestrian bridge. Sample taken on sediment at low tide at change of direction in creek.

properties.title: 1902: TOXIC SOUP!
properties.description: *Stauffer affiliate Vigorit Powder began making and shipping dynamite.*

properties.title: 1823 : OHLONE SHELLMOUNDS
properties.description:
*xuƒçyun (Huichin) was the home territory for Chochenyo speaking Ohlone people.*

*[influence of ohlone on creek]*

*Huchiun land was awarded to Francisco Castro for his service in the Mexican army, and the Mission Dolores priests surrendered the land.*

properties.title: 1870: EUROPEAN INFLUENCE, RICHARD STEGE
properties.description: *Stege married Minna Quilfeldt, a wealthy widow, and acquired 600 acres of grazing land, encompassing what is now the 19.5-acre Booker T. Anderson Park.*

properties.title: 1897: TOXIC SOUP!
properties.description: *Stauffer Chemical began making sulfuric acid. It disposed off byproduct - iron-pyrite cinders and later other toxics like arsenic, lead, mercury, benzene, acetone and PCBs as fill in today's marshes.*

properties.title: Mira Vista Branch
properties.description: The Mira Vista aka Tewksbury branch -the northernmost branch, can be seen in Richmond‚Äôs Mira Vista Park.

properties.title: Pointsett Branch
properties.description: The middle branch, visible in El Cerrito‚Äôs Poinsett Park.

properties.title: Canyon Trail Branch
properties.description: Canyon Trail, Bishop, or Stege branch (the southernmost branch, flows through El Cerrito‚Äôs Canyon Trail Park.

properties.title: What is a Watershed?
properties.description: A watershed, also known as a drainage basin, is all of the land that drains to a particular body of water- in this case Baxter Creek and ultimately San Francisco Bay.

properties.title: Watershed
properties.description: Within the Baxter Creek watershed are several sub-watersheds, defined by hills and low points. The low points are where the creeks flow - either openly or in pipes underground.

properties.title: Branches
properties.description: The Baxter Creek watershed wasn‚Äôt always so fragmented and confusing. Clues to its important past can be glimpsed today, with a little determined sleuthing and some storm drain maps. Today‚Äôs storm drain system takes the three branches: Mira Vista, Pointsett, or Canyon Trail-Gateway.

properties.title: Baxter Creek meets the Bay at Stage Marsh
Elevation
properties.description: Originating in springs at elevations of close to 400 feet, the creek drops to sea level in just a little over two miles as it enters the Bay.

properties.title: Size
properties.description: Compared to large watersheds like nearby Wildcat or San Pablo Creek, which encompass approximately 13 and 41 square miles respectively, the Baxter Creek watershed is small, draining only approximately 1.92 square miles.

properties.title: Information
properties.description:
It was [is] once an important resource for the Native Americans and wildlife who lived along its banks.

Today it is the focus of an ambitious watershed-awareness program that is helping residents of Richmond and El Cerrito learn about their landscape, as altered as it may be, and to become watershed stewards by engaging in hands-on restoration activities.

properties.title: The Path of the Creek
properties.description:
Like many urban streams, Baxter Creek (also known as Stege, Bishop, Canyon Trail, and Tewksbury Creek) has been much altered from its original condition...


 having been rerouted in sections, hidden underground in others, and even‚Äîas with many urban creeks‚Äîconfined in concrete channels. 


Like many urban watersheds, the Baxter Creek watershed has been covered with buildings and impermeable surfaces like asphalt and concrete...


Because many sections of the creek flow in culverts beneath the ground, people find it difficult to understand where the creek comes from and where it goes...

properties.title: Branches join
properties.description: At this juncture, the three branches converge to flow in a concrete channel beneath Interstate 80.

properties.title: The Friends of Baxter Creek
properties.description:
Despite the fact that much of Baxter Creek runs underground, the Baxter Creek watershed is full of restoration successes. Local and state government, regulatory agencies, and non-profits have been involved in supporting and funding these projects. 

However, it is the people in the community, who formed and participate in the Friends of Baxter Creek, which have provided the vision and drive to make these projects happen. 

The Friends of Baxter Creek are an active force for positive change in their community.

properties.title: Information
properties.description: Investigations conducted in the 1970s by the California Department of Health Services (now the State of California Department of Toxic Substances Control) and the San Francisco Bay Regional Water Quality Control Board (RWQCB) documented releases of hazardous substances onto the ground and into ponds, sumps, and ditches. Consequently, the site was listed on the California State Superfund List in January 1983.

properties.title: POINSETT PARK
properties.description:
Today‚Äôs storm drain system divides into three branches:

1. The Mira Vista aka Tewksbury branch (the northernmost branch, which can be seen in Richmond‚Äôs Mira Vista Park)
2. *The Poinsett branch* pinned here (the middle branch, visible in El Cerrito‚Äôs Poinsett Park). 
3. The Canyon Trail, Bishop, or Stege branch (the southernmost branch, which flows through El Cerrito‚Äôs Canyon Trail Park)‚Äîand joins them together into one waterway just south of Angelo‚Äôs Delicatessen, near MacDonald and San Pablo Avenues. At this juncture, the three branches converge to flow in a concrete channel beneath Interstate 80.


Video shows the prototype of the step pool infrastructure for creek restoration
*The creek in its natural state disappeared, probably moved to make room for holes and turf, although its water was obviously pumped and used to create special ‚Äúwater features,‚Äù such as a pond.*

properties.title: 1949: [add title]
properties.description: *California Cap a dynamite company, shut down and was purchased by UC Berkeley. Remediation created today‚Äôs attractive salt marsh.*

properties.title: 1949 Cover Up
properties.description: *The Poinsett Park section of the creek was put in a pipe underground, as were many sections of the creek in the Richmond flatlands as part of ‚Äúimprovements‚Äù to the storm drain system.*

properties.title: 1956: ZENECA'S TOXIC SOUP
properties.description: *Seaport community was torn down and Stauffer Chemical was bought by Zeneca, which claims to be remediating the site today.*

properties.title: 1996: CREEK DAYLIGHTED
properties.description: *The Poinsett Park branch of Baxter Creek was daylighted.*

properties.title: Metal contamination
properties.description: Copper, Mercury, Zinc, Nickel

properties.title: Metal contamination
properties.description: Lead, Copper and Chromium

properties.title: Pesticide contamination
properties.description: DDT

properties.title: Did you know...
properties.description: In the flatlands of Richmond, jackrabbits were still so plentiful as late as the early 1900s that operators of the East Shore and Suburban Railway‚Äîa local trolley line‚Äîstopped to shoot at them.

properties.title: Huchiun Territory
properties.description:
Huchiuns who live[d] closer to the Bay caught 

mussels

California oysters

seabirds like cormorants and grebes, 

sea otters

seals

sea lions

properties.title: Infrastructure
properties.description:
Daylighting and restoration efforts
all images and graph by Matt Falcone, UC Berkeley 2022

properties.title: 1900's
properties.description:
By the early 1900s, Baxter Creek may have become an intermittent stream. 

In his 1910 paper on the shellmounds at Ellis Landing (west of the Baxter Creek watershed), UC Berkeley archaeologist N.C. Nelson found only a:

‚Äúvery slight superficial indication of old creeks that once crossed the area . . . one or two of these run between Stege and the Berkeley Hills‚Äù.

 (The Berkeley Hills in the Richmond area are also known as the San Pablo Ridge. 

The Mira Vista Golf Course lies on the west side of the Ridge, where the Baxter Creek branches originate)

properties.title: Creek Source
properties.description:
*1910*

Grazing and other land-uses had likely already degraded many of the East Bay‚Äôs smaller streams, but it is also possible that Baxter Creek dried up in the summer months, or that the many farms along its banks were diverting or pumping most of its water. 

*Today*

the creek flows year round, fed by the springs, and by runoff from irrigated golf courses, lawns, and gardens, as well as other urban sources...

properties.title: More on Stege...
properties.description:
Richard Stege created elaborate gardens on his estate, planting **palms and other trees, along with beds of roses, violets, and carnations.**

 He also dammed (and probably straightened) portions of Baxter Creek and possibly another creek that appears to have flowed through the site to the south of it, to create a series of ponds for rearing frogs. Stege began operating a frog farm, selling frogs for $2 apiece to San Francisco restaurants for their tasty legs, a popular delicacy. 

...His business became California's largest and most successful frog ranch.

Just another story of capitalism and natural resource degradation...
